lexUnit.name: gibber.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: speak rapidly and unintelligibly, typically through fear or shock.

sentence.text: “ I 'm the tar baby … ” he gibbered .
This is funny , gibbered a small part of his mind , why am I rising ?
They shrieked and gibbered as blazing air surrounded them .

Another car followed him for half a mile , imagined menace in the rear view mirror growing with every second , until he swerved abruptly into a layby and let it pass , gibbering the registration number to himself as he scrabbled in the glove compartment for a piece of paper on which to write it down .
Ashen-faced , she was gibbering quietly to herself , her petrol-sodden hair plastered to her head and her dripping gown showing her legs almost to the crotch .
Yet with hands clasped he whimpers and gibbers with such desperate ardour for his own preservation , on his knees .
No voices gibbered at him from dark corners .
Daemons howled and gibbered in the ruins of ancient settlements .
Grimm gibbered in Squattish , obviously regretting his impetuous excursion to visit the war front .
He growled and gibbered at them like a witch-hare and those nearest to him fell back in fear .

I was stuck there like a flying buttress between the floor and the pillar , and Jamie was still gibbering away to the girl about the sound a Triumph makes and the high-speed runs she 'd done up the side of Loch Lomond at night .
What the hell are you gibbering about ? "
I do n't know about the food , because I 'll have to cook it myself , but I promise you we wo n't gibber or wear paper caps .
Something else Hugh saw nearly made him gibber .
The sensible thing to do , having made the initial impact , was to walk off in a slow and menacing way , leaving Quigley to gibber .
He gibbered and choked over an appeal for mercy .
